_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The stationary source is considered the entire Upstate Niagara Cooperative, Inc. facility located at 1730 Dale Road in Buffalo, New York.  The stationary source is involved in production of various milk and dairy products.  Ammonia liquified under pressure is the only regulated chemical exceeding a threshold quantity under 40 CFR Part 68.

         Upstate Niagara Cooperative, Inc. proactively uses the OSHA Process Safety Management program required under 29 CFR 1910.119, in conjunction with the additional off-site considerations covered in the 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D, as an accidental release prevention program.  These documents are considered working programs and are used by facility personnel as the procedural standards for preventing accidental releases.  

          Emergency response policies for the facility include an integration of the plans required under 29 CFR 1910.120(q) "Emergency Response to Hazardous Releases", 29 CFR 1910.38(a) "Emergency Action Plan", 40 CFR Part 355 "Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know", 29 CFR 1910.119 "Process Safety Management", and 40 CFR Part 68 "Risk Management Program".  Integration of these programs for the Upstate Niagara Cooperative, Inc. facility increases the usefullness of the emergency preparedness activities by decreasing the burden associated with maintaining multiple programs.  In general, Upstate Niagara Cooperative, Inc. performs only secondary emergency response measures with properly trained in-house personnel.  Local and private emergency response agencies handle all major emergencies.  Community notification policies are in place in the event of an emergency with potential off-site impacts.  

         The accidental release prevention program integrates the OSHA Process Safety Management program required under 29 CFR 1910.119 and the additional off-site considerations covered in 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D, as an accidental release prevention program.  One of the most important aspects of

the prevention program is adherance to the mechanical integrity portion of the PSM Program, using specific standards established for the ammonia refrigeration industry by the equipment manufacturer and/or the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).

          There have been no reportable accidents in the past five (5) years.  

          Changes to improve safety at the facility have included the completion of Phase 2 of a 3 phased electrical upgrade throughout the plant.
